SEARCH
Package com.nickslibrary.datastructures.trees

Class BinarySearchTree<T extends Comparable<T>>

java.lang.Object
com.nickslibrary.datastructures.trees.BinarySearchTree<T>
public class BinarySearchTree<T extends Comparable<T>> extends Object

  • Constructor Details

    • BinarySearchTree

      public BinarySearchTree()
      Constructs an empty Binary Search Tree.

  • Method Details

    • insert

      public void insert(T value)
      Inserts a value into the Binary Search Tree.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to insert into the tree

    • contains

      public boolean contains(T value)
      Checks if the tree contains a given value.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to search for
      Returns:
      true if the value is found, false otherwise

    • inorderTraversal

      public void inorderTraversal()
      Performs an in-order traversal of the tree and prints the values. This traversal visits nodes in ascending order for a BST.

    • delete

      public void delete(T value)
      Deletes the specified value from the binary search tree, if it exists. If the value is not found, the tree remains unchanged.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to be deleted from the tree

    • preorderTraversal

      public List<T> preorderTraversal()
      Performs a preorder traversal of the binary search tree and returns a list containing the elements in preorder sequence (Root → Left → Right).
      Returns:
      a list of elements in preorder traversal order

    • postorderTraversal

      public List<T> postorderTraversal()
      Performs a postorder traversal of the tree and returns a list of elements. In postorder traversal, each node is visited after its left and right subtrees. I'm including a postorder traversal method for completeness, but in practice
      Returns:
      a List containing elements in postorder traversal order the serialized return is handled by preorderTraversal and deleteAll is handled by setting root to null and letting the GC take care of dereferenced memory

    • levelOrderTraversal

      public List<T> levelOrderTraversal()
      Performs a level-order traversal (breadth-first) of the tree and returns a list of elements in that order.
      Returns:
      a List containing elements in level-order traversal order

    • get

      public T get(T value)
      Retrieves a value from the tree, if it exists.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to search for
      Returns:
      the found value, or null if not found

    • getNode

      public BinaryTreeNode<T> getNode(T value)
      Retrieves the node containing the given value.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to search for
      Returns:
      the found node, or null if not found

    • findMin

      public T findMin()
      Finds and returns the minimum value in the Binary Search Tree. The minimum value is located at the leftmost node of the tree.
      Returns:
      the minimum value in the tree, or null if the tree is empty

    • findMax

      public T findMax()
      Finds and returns the maximum value in the Binary Search Tree. The maximum value is located at the rightmost node of the tree.
      Returns:
      the maximum value in the tree, or null if the tree is empty

    • getHeight

      public int getHeight()
      Computes the height of the Binary Search Tree. The height of a tree is defined as the number of edges on the longest path from the root to a leaf node. An empty tree has a height of -1, and a tree with only a root node has a height of 0.
      Returns:
      the height of the tree, or -1 if the tree is empty

    • size

      public int size()
      Computes the total number of nodes in the Binary Search Tree. This represents the total elements stored in the tree.
      Returns:
      the number of nodes in the tree, or 0 if the tree is empty

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      Checks if the Binary Search Tree is empty. A tree is considered empty if it has no nodes.
      Returns:
      true if the tree is empty, false otherwise

    • clear

      public void clear()
      Removes all elements from the Binary Search Tree, making it empty. This sets the root to null, allowing Java's garbage collector to reclaim memory used by the nodes.
